awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mitigating Emergent System Behavior through System Evolvability
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this collaborative project is to discover the principles governing the evolvability of complex engineered systems (CES) and understand how service-phase evolution can be used to reduce negative emergent behavior in the face of unforeseen future needs. While providing essential benefits to society, complex systems are unusually challenging to design because they have (i) elaborate internal interactions, (ii) long development times, (iii) lifecycles associated with extended service windows, and (iv) exhibit unanticipated emergent behavior. To address these challenges, this research project will begin by conducting empirical studies to understand how existing CES have evolved in-service in response to emergent needs. These studies will be used to draw insights about why certain CES are more effective at evolving than others. Different measures and models of evolvability will be then be explored and validated to guide designers in manipulating the evolution of CES. Finally, this project will explore how information about service-phase evolution can be integrated into a value model, and how different evolution strategies impact overall system value. 

If successful, this work will begin to address a recurring theme from recent CES workshops highlighting the need to control and capitalize on system evolvability. Results from this project will significantly advance understanding of the relationship between system design and the tendency for systems to mitigate emergent behavior through evolution by identifying and cataloging useful principles that can be accessed by practicing engineers. By exploring metrics to characterize system evolvability, this research will facilitate the synthesis of information from various design tools to describe system capabilities and quantify the impact provided by various evolution possibilities. Linking these insights to value-driven design will study the relationship between evolvability and system value while furthering the use and validation of this design approach. Lessons learned and contributions of this work will be disseminated through publications, internet-available design camp teaching modules, interactions with industry supports, and at conferences. Finally, student involvement through summer design camps at both NCSU and BYU campuses will grant first-hand experience in system design and bring together students of diverse backgrounds and thinking.

por.por_cntn:
Large scale systems (highways, communication networks, aircraft, military systems, etc.) offer immense value to society. Yet, inefficiencies that develop over the lifespan of these systems can be costly to overcome if the proper response strategies were not considered at the time of original design. Researchers and practitioners of systems engineering have a responsibility to study how systems can be more effectively changed (or evolved) or time so that these inefficiencies can be overcome or reduced. This research project was proposed to address the lack of knowledge associated with modeling system longevity and changeability in a way that better allowed engineers to understand the ramifications of their original design choices. By incorporating the knowledge that we have learned from this project into a decision making environment that considers the multidisciplinary interactions present in complex systems, we can reduce the costs and inefficiencies of large scale systems and offer greater value to society.

The outcomes of this project contribute to our discipline’s ability to design systems required to remain in operation for long periods of time (decades). A driving focus of our effort was to identify and understand the characteristics of previously designed systems that were kept in service for decades because they offered enough value to the user. Research by our team has identified that excess – the surplus in a component or system once the necessities of current requirements have been met – is a critical characteristic of systems with operational longevity. Our initial efforts explored systems where a significant amount of historical knowledge could be used to identify the types of excess present in the system. We were able to develop an approach that mapped this excess directly to system longevity, creating an initial framework that engineers could use to inform their design decisions.

The success of this early work led to two additional questions that were studied during the period of this award. We needed to understand how excess should be optimally allocated within a system when the requirements associated with the system were uncertain. This uncertainty was incorporated into an decision making framework where system value was maximized by incorporating excess into the system prior to it being fielded. Building on our original analysis of an aircraft carrier, we also considered a common military ground vehicle and product designed for use in developing countries.

The second question explored how to model the excess within a system when the engineer did not have access to a significant amount of historical knowledge available. Because excess directly relates to the system architecture and the specifications under which the system components operate, there was a need to build a mapping function that considered component interfaces and the properties of the components comprising the system. Our research toward answering this question has resulted in an excess taxonomy that builds on existing taxonomies in our discipline, providing a common language and measuring system that can be used by practicing engineers. We were able to demonstrate how a lack of excess could create bottlenecks that block system change and how the choice of system architecture combined with proper allocations of excess could be used to create the most efficient systems capable of long lifespans.

The outcomes of this project improve our ability to mathematically modeling the evolvability of a system so that it can react to unforeseen changes in requirements while still offering enough value to warrant its continued use. This modeling allows for more informed design decisions to be made before the system goes into service. Specifically, we can now mathematically model reconfigurability, model different types, locations, and forms of excess, and design in such excess to have maximum utility when new requirements must be met. Quantifiable functions and models are valuable to engineers because they enable numerical design aids, and these can be used by the many disciplines involved in making design decisions related to systems that stay in service for a very long time.

As part of this award two graduate students (MS) and one undergraduate student were trained at NC State University. Four graduate students (3 MS, 1 PhD) and two undergraduate students were trained at BYU. Publications include four journal publications in print, two journal publications under review, four conference papers, and five thesis/dissertations. The students trained on this grant now possess expert-level knowledge related to system engineering and will hopefully create solutions that offer a greater value to society.
